case_vignette:
A 45-year-old African-American woman comes to the physician after an episode of hemoptysis. Over the past 8 months, she has had a nonproductive cough, fatigue, and a 9-kg (20-lb) weight loss. She drinks a glass of wine every night and does not smoke. She has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. She does not take any medications. She has never traveled out of the country. She works as an accountant. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows a 2.5-cm nodule with irregular borders at the apex of the left lung with no mediastinal or hilar enlargement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 
The text should be be rewritten to remove all gender-specific references, such as "African-American woman" and "accountant" (which is a profession that is more commonly associated with women). Here is the rewritten text:
A 45-year-old African-American patient comes to the physician after an episode of hemoptysis. Over the past 8 months, they have had a nonproductive cough, fatigue, and a 9-kg (20-lb) weight loss. They drink a glass of wine every night and do not smoke. They have a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. They do not take any medications. They have never traveled out of the country. They work as an accountant. Their temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows a 2.5-cm nodule with irregular borders at the apex of the left lung with no mediastinal or hilar enlargement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

Note: I've kept the profession as "accountant" as it is a neutral term, but if you want to make it more neutral, you could change it to something like "financial professional" or "office worker". 

Also, I've kept the patient's age and other demographic information as it is not gender-specific. If you want to make the text more neutral, you could remove the age and other demographic
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing a nonproductive cough, fatigue, and I've lost about 20 pounds over the last 8 months. Recently, I also had an episode of coughing up blood.
Have you experienced any fever or night sweats along with these symptoms?
No, I haven't experienced any fever or night sweats.
Do you have a history of smoking or exposure to substances like asbestos?
No, I do not smoke and have not been exposed to substances like asbestos.
Have you had any previous medical issues or diagnoses related to your lungs or respiratory system?
No, I have not had any previous medical issues or diagnoses related to my lungs or respiratory system.
Do you have any family history of cancer or genetic diseases?
I haven't mentioned any family history of cancer or genetic diseases.
Have you had any recent imaging studies such as a chest X-ray or CT scan?
Yes, I had a chest X-ray that showed a 2.5-cm nodule with irregular borders at the apex of my left lung.
Final Diagnosis: Lung Cancer
